channel.title: Got Ya on Gonzalo's thoughts
channel.description: Recent content in Got Ya on Gonzalo's thoughts

item.title: EDITOR variable as a script
item.description: I’ve decided I’m going to start writing again, even small things. This week I was trying to create a Kubernetes cluster using Kops. In the end it didn’t work (mainly because it uses a Classic LoadBalancer and we don’t have public IPs in that VPC)

item.title: Dock disappeared in MacOS Catalina
item.description: Yes. I feel your pain. That little bar at the bottom of your screen is no longer visible after you upgraded to macOS Catalina. Well, here I am, to help you before Apple does.

item.title: Metadata abuse in AWS
item.description: Introduction A few weeks ago there was an attack on Capital One’s AWS infrastructure that lead to the compromise of personal information on around 100M people. AWS is putting great effort in avoiding S3 buckets configured for public access.

item.title: Configuration in AWS is difficult
item.description: I’ve been doing some research on credentials compromise and abuse in AWS. In the process, it was obvious that the main mitigation would be (is) to minimise the permissions assigned to the EC2 instance profile, applying the “least privilege principle”.

item.title: Trivial error with Bitbucket API
item.description: UPDATE: A few days after publication, the documentation now includes some examples. Well done, Atlassian. Most people in the software industry know Jira. For better or for worse, it’s the most used product for managing tickets, requests, bugs…

item.title: AWS CloudWatch alarms
item.description: One of the things less obvious for anyone trying to setup Cloudwatch alarms is the treatment of missing points. You create an alarm, to detect too many 5xx errors in your ELB.

item.title: AWS ELB in Apache logs
item.description: So you are using AWS Elastic Load Balancer in front of a set of Apache httpd servers and you’ve discovered that your Apache logs are full of garbage. Here comes a set of tips to improve your logging:

item.title: Jetty
item.description: Lately I’ve had three different issues with Jetty. Two of them were those kind of issues that are not directly related to the problem. The third proved to be a bit more tricky.

item.title: PDOException
item.description: Small and uninteresting post. But I’ve been dealing with an issue for hours and maybe somebody can benefit from this in the future. While trying to index using Sphinx, I was getting the following error

item.title: Tipping point
item.description: I’m happy. I was developing a feature that allows to export from my showcase project Whendoigo to TripIt. I was using a gem from TripIt. A gem is kind of a library for Ruby (sort of jar for Java).

item.title: I was sure it was my fault...
item.description: … but it wasn’t. In the last week or so, I’ve been hitting against a wall because of two different bugs. I was sure that both bugs were my fault. It took me ages (of a scarce spare time) trying different things, searching for similar problems, until in both cases I finally came to an issue in different tools.

item.title: Firmware upgrade for Xperia U in Linux (II)
item.description: [Long post] Edited (08th-Jun-2014): Updated the firmware download site. In my previous post I explained that one of the things that made the installing process more difficult was the lack of a general picture of the process.

item.title: Firmware upgrade for Xperia U in Linux (I)
item.description: About a year ago I received some wonderful presents from a group of friends :D. One of them was an Xperia U. Sony Xperia U (ST25i) has a stock Android 2.

item.title: OptionalDataException while reading JMS message
item.description: We’ve been dealing with another bug in JMS code. The symptom was blocked queues and the following exception: javax.jms.JMSException: getObject [...] Caused by: java.io.OptionalDataException at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readObject0(ObjectInputStream.java:1325) at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readObject(ObjectInputStream.java:348) at java.util.HashMap.readObject(HashMap.java:1066) In trying to reproduce the issue people in the team introduced a non-serializable object, but they got an exception sending the message (Caused by: javax.

item.title: Weird IE9 bug
item.description: This last two weeks I have dealt with a weird bug in IE9. The problem appeared in a legacy web application. The issue reported by the user was a combo that didn’t drop down.

item.title: Savon.rb and sequences
item.description: As I wrote in my last post, I’ve recently learned it is important to be able to show what you’ve been doing. So I’m trying to increase the posts on a number of small problems I find in my daily job, and in my hobby projects.

item.title: Xerces, Xalan and Saxon, more recipes
item.description: In a previous post I proposed some tips for trying to manage and control the hell of XML and XPATH parsers. However, as one reader pointed (EDIT: This was in my original blog), those tips sometimes are not enough.

item.title: Xerces and Xalan: Recipes for the win
item.description: OK. I have explained why Xerces and Xalan are a source of problems, and I have explained why you shouldn’t use System.setProperty to resolve them. In this post I wan’t to give a few recipes to resolve Xerces and Xalan problems.

item.title: Things about Xerces, Xalan and Saxon I didn't know (III)
item.description: In my previous entry, I tried to explain why Xerces and Xalan are so complicated. In this entry I want to focus in System.setProperty. Because, as I said that is the usual solution you are going to find when you need a specific parser for whatever reason.

item.title: Things about Xerces, Xalan and Saxon I didn't know (II)
item.description: I said in the previous post that Xalan and Xerces sometimes look like magic. So what are they and why are so complicated?. Xerces is a Java library that helps parsing, validating and managing XML documents.

item.title: Things about Xerces, Xalan and Saxon I didn't know (I)
item.description: These days I’m getting very proud of myself. I’m acting less as a project manager and more as a true Scrum Manager. I go to the scrum, listen, and a great deal of my work that day is trying to solve problems for the team.

item.title: Notes to a newbie spring-mvc developer
item.description: Activate log4j. Without it you’re lost Look through the log to see if you’re getting the RequestMapping through Spring. If you are not despite correct annotations, see this post. In particular if you’ve got Spring Security installed, for Goodness sake, don’t forget these lines:

item.title: More Mantis problems
item.description: I have been fighting with PHP, Mantis and SOAP since my last post. Now I think I have discovered a bug when uploading via Mantis SOAP a binary file. It’s great being able to debug a PHP application.

item.title: Mantis on SQL Server
item.description: [Technical post] I’ve been busy last couple of days trying to make Mantis work with a Microsoft SQL Server database on a Windows Server 2003. Many people would ask why to use MSSQL instead of Mysql, a much better DBMS, not mention the OS election.
